revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:The Malachite Box 1939.jpg|thumb|Title page of the 1st edition of ''The Malachite Box'' (as a single volume), 1939.]] '''''The Malachite Box''''' or '''''The Malachite Casket''''' ({{lang-rus|Малахитовая шкатулка|r=Malakhitovaya Shkatulka|p=mɐləˈxʲitəvɐjə ʂkɐˈtulkə}}) is a book of [[fairy tales]] and [[Folklore|folk tales]] (also known as ''[[skaz]]'') of the [[Ural (region)|Ural]] region of Russia compiled by [[Pavel Bazhov]] and published from 1936 to 1945. It is written in contemporary language and blends elements of everyday life with fantastic characters. It was awarded the [[Stalin prize]] in 1942. Bazhov's stories are based on the [[Oral tradition|oral lore]] of the [[miner]]s and [[gold prospector]]s. The first edition of ''The Malachite Box'' was released on 28 January 1939. It consisted of 14 stories and an introduction, which contained some information about the life, industry and culture of the Urals and which the author tried to include into every edition of the collection. Later versions contained more than 40 stories. Not all stories are equally popular nowadays. The most popular tales were written between 1936 and 1939: "[[The Mistress of the Copper Mountain (fairy tale)|The Mistress of the Copper Mountain]]" and its continuation "[[The Malachite Casket (fairy tale)|The Malachite Casket]]", "[[The Stone Flower]]" and its continuation "The Master Craftsman", "[[Silver Hoof]]", "Cat's Ears", "[[Sinyushka's Well]]", "The Manager's Boot-Soles". Among the later stories, "A Fragile Twig" (1940), "[[The Fire-Fairy]]" (1940), "Tayutka's Mirror" (1941), "Ivanko Krylatko" (1943), "[[That Spark of Life]]" (1943) are popular. The characters of the [[Ural Mountains]] folklore such as [[the Mistress of the Copper Mountain]] became very well known after their appearance in Pavel Bazhov's ''The Malachite Box''. == Background == In the 1930s the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] greatly encouraged the interest in the past of the country and the people. The Party paid a lot of attention to the development of the [[History|historical science]]. [[Maxim Gorky]] initiated the publication of such books as ''The History of Factories and Plants'' ({{lang-rus|История фабрик и заводов|Istorija fabrik i zavodov|links=no}}). The initiative was supported by the Communist Party. History books and various [[historical fiction]] titles were published one after another.Batin 1983, p. 1. General interest in the history of the country transformed into the interest in [[folk art]] and [[folklore]]. The famous folklore expert [[Nikolay Andreyev (folklorist)|Nikolay Andreyev]] later wrote about that period that the folklore collections "have never been published before in such quantities, not even in the "Golden Age" of the [[folkloristics]] in the 60s". Journalists, students, and members of [[Komsomol]] started collecting folklore.Blazhes 2003, p. 6. At the [[First Сongress of the Soviet Writers]] Maxim Gorky reminded the writers that "the art of words begins with folklore" and encouraged them to collect and study it. It was supposed to be used as a model example of the literature. == Overview == Pavel Bazhov was born at the Urals. He knew its geography, topography, [[natural resource]]s, and was very proud of both the beauty of the Urals and its people. He stated that his main reason for writing was to suppress the pain after the loss of his only son Alexey in 1935. Mark Lipovetsky believed the tense situation in the author's life could partially explain the depth and the sombre [[Tone (literature)|tone]] of his early tales,Lipovetsky 2014, p. 215. which made them so popular among the adult readers. He suggested that the tales carried the sign of deep terror and trauma, which Bazhov endured between January 1937 and 1938, and noted that ''The Malachite Box'' "is filled with unprecedented for Soviet (and especially children's) literature horror". At that time Bazhov was fired from [[Sverdlovsk Publishing House]], where he had worked since 1931, and expelled from the Communist Party for "glorification of people's enemies" in his recent book. His past as a member of the [[Socialist Revolutionary Party]] and a [[seminary]] teacher was also questionable.Lipovetsky 2014, p. 214. He was once summoned for interrogation by [[NKVD]], but luckily his investigator was arrested the day before the meeting. The author was reinstated in the Communist Party in 1938. Nevertheless, a lot of the stories were written between January 1937 and 1938. Bazhov later said: "It happened to be such a black stripe that I was at loose ends. So I started to work on some old ideas."{{cite journal|last=Komlev|first=Andrey |year=2004|title=Bazhov i Sverdlovskoe otdelenie Sojuza sovetskih pisatelej |script-title = ru:Бажов и Свердловское отделение Союза советских писателей | trans-title =Bazhov and the Sverdlovsk department of the Union of the Soviet writers|journal=Ural|location=Yekaterinburg |volume=1|url= http://magazines.russ.ru/ural/2004/1/koml5.html|language=Russian}} During the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Great Patriotic War]] (1941–1945) Bazhov switched to the patriotic tales, the task that he considered his duty as the patriot. The distinctive feature of the later stories is the strengthening of the social motive, such as confrontation based on [[social class]], and the decrease in poetic and supernatural scenarios. The tales are told from the point of view of the imaginary Grandpa Slyshko ({{lang-rus|Дед Слышко|Ded Slyshko|links=no}}; [[Literal translation|lit.]] "Old Man Listenhere").Balina 2005, p. 115. Slyshko is the old miner from a factory who rememberes the [[Serfdom]] era. In the stories written at the end of the Great Patriotic War and in the post-war years, Bazhov introduced the new narrator. His new stories were told by a different type of the miner: the patriotic participant of the [[Russian Civil War]] who fought for the [[Red Army]] and later helped to build the new [[socialism|socialist society]]. The tales can be divided into several groups: the series about craftsmen (the most famous tales are "[[The Stone Flower]]", "The Master Craftsman", "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#A Fragile Twig|A Fragile Twig]]"); the tales about some mysterious forces, which contain surreal plots and mythical creatures ("[[The Mistress of the Copper Mountain (fairy tale)|The Mistress of the Copper Mountain]]", "[[The Malachite Casket (fairy tale)|The Malachite Casket]]", "[[Sinyushka's Well]]", "Cat's Ears"); the satirical tales about [[gold prospector]]s or greedy [[bailiff]]s ("The Manager's Boot-Soles", "Sochen and His Stones");{{cite web|url=http://lib.pushkinskijdom.ru/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=6NBdNSUcQ7c=&tabid=10547|title=Bazhov Pavel Petrovitch|work=The Russian Academy of Sciences Electronic Library IRLI|publisher=The Russian Literature Institute of the Pushkin House, [[Russian Academy of Sciences|RAS]]|pages=151–152|language=Russian|accessdate=25 November 2015}} the tales about [[mine exploration|mine explorers]] ("Sinyushka's Well"). During the Great Patriotic War and in the post-war years, Bazhov started writing about Soviet armourers, steel-makers, and teemers, emphasizing the patriotic pride of the Russian workers. He also penned some stories about the Russian communist leaders, [[Vladimir Lenin]] and [[Joseph Stalin]]. Furthermore, Pavel Bazhov indicated that his stories can be divided into two groups based on [[Tone (literature)|tone]]: "child-toned" (e.g. "[[The Fire-Fairy]]", "[[Silver Hoof]]"), and "adult-toned" ("The Stone Flower", "Marko's Hill").{{cite web|url=http://bibliogid.ru/krug-chteniya/mify-legendy-narodnye-skazki/1019-bazhov-p-p-malakhitovaya-shkatulka|title=Bazhov P. P. The Malachite Box|date=13 May 2006|publisher=Bibliogid|language=Russian|accessdate=25 November 2015}}Bazhov 1952 (1), p. 246. Denis Zherdev divided the stories into "gold" and "malachite" series, which begin with "[[Beloved Name]]" and "The Mistress of the Copper Mountain" respectively.{{cite web|url=http://mith.ru/alb/lib/bazov/mim2_1.htm|title=Poetika skazov Bazhova |script-title = ru:Поэтика сказов Бажова| trans-title =The poetics of Bazhov's stories|last=Zherdev|first=Denis|publisher=Research Library Mif.Ru|language=Russian|accessdate=14 December 2015}} == Publication == In the mid-1930s [[Sverdlovsk Publishing House]] decided to publish the collection ''Prerevolutionary Folklore of [[Ural (region)|the Urals]]'' ({{lang-rus|Дореволюционный фольклор на Урале|Dorevoljucionnyj folklor na Urale|links=no}}). In the summer of 1934 the folklorist [[Vladimir Biryukov]] was offered to make such a collection. The historian Andrey Ladeyshchikov became its [[chief editor]].Blazhes 2003, p. 7. From August to December 1935 Biryukov collected folklore at the Ural Mountains. He was supposed to finish the book by January 1935, however, it was not completed on February. Biryukov wrote in the diary that "the classification, introduction, and the [[bibliography]]" were needed. Several sections of the collection were not yet ready as well. Biryukov mostly worked on [[Folk music|songs]], folk riddles, and [[fairy tales]].Batin 1983, p. 2. On 25 February 1395 Biryukov met with Yelizaveta Blinova, the new chief editor of ''Prerevolutionary Folklore of the Urals'' appointed instead of Andrey Ladeyshchikov. She insisted on including the folklore of the [[working class]], although Biryukov claimed that it would be impossible to find. Blinova consulted with journalists, ethnographers, and writers (including Pavel Bazhov) and asked them to write down some workers' folklore. She added their stories to the collection. Blinova's initiative inspired Bazhov to start working on his stories.Blazhes 2003, p. 8. Bazhov, who was an employee of the same publishing house since 1931,{{cite web|url=http://www.publiclibrary.ru/readers/read/litvzgljad-bazhov.htm |trans-title= P. P. Bazhov's works. A literary opinion |title=Творчество П. П. Бажова. Литературный взгляд.|work=Read, Novouralsk!|publisher=The Novouralsk City District Public Library|language=Russian|accessdate=2 December 2015}} suggested that she include some stories that he had heard at the [[Polevskoy Copper Smelting Plant]] from the miners' storyteller Vasily Hmelinin ({{lang-rus|Василий Хмелинин|links=no}}), nicknamed "Grandpa Slyshko" by children (''slysh-ka'' [[Literal translation|literally]] means "Listen here!"). Bazhov later wrote about Blinova:
She raised a question: why were there no workers' folklore? Vladimir Pavlovich [Biryukov] replied that he had not been able to find it anywhere. I was dismayed: how can that be true? I've heard this workers' folklore in abundance, I've heard the whole ''skazy''. And I brought to her "[[Beloved Name]]" as an example.{{cite journal|last=Blazhes|first=Valentin |authorlink=Valentin Blazhes |year=2003|title=К истории создания бажовских сказов |trans-title=About the history of creation of Bazhov's stories |journal=Izvestiya of the Ural State University|publisher=The [[Ural State University]] |issue=28|pages=8 |language=Russian |quote=Она поставила вопрос: почему же нет рабочего фольклора? Владимир Павлович ответил, что он его нигде не может найти. Меня это просто задело: как так, рабочего фольклора нет? Я сам сколько угодно этого рабочего фольклора слыхал, слыхал целые сказы. И я в виде образца принес им “Дорогое имячко”.}}
Pavel Bazhov had heard the ''skaz'' from Vasily Hmelinin in 1892-1895, and wrote it down from memory,Blazhes 2003, p. 9. trying to use the miners' [[natural language]] where possible, as he was always fascinated with miners' [[colloquialism]]s.{{cite AV media | people = Vorontsov, Olgerd (director) | date = 1968 | title = Сказы уральских гор | trans-title = Tales of the Ural Mountains | medium = | language = Russian | url = http://www.net-film.ru/en/film-55307/ | access-date =8 December 2015 | format =Motion picture | time = 37:10 | publisher =Russian Archive of Documentary Films and Newsreels| location =[[Sverdlovsk Film Studio]] }} His prerevolutionary records, which consisted of six notebooks, were lost during the [[Russian Civil War]]. Bazhov introduced Vasily Hmelinin in the stories as the narrator Grandpa Slyshko. In July 1936 Blinova left Sverdlovsk Publishing House. Bazhov became the chief editor, only to be replaced by Ladeyshchikov again. The collection was eventually published under Ladeyshchikov's name on December 1936. There were three of Bazhov's stories in it: "Beloved Name", "The Great Snake", and "The Mistress of the Copper Mountain". Prior to the publication, the [[Detskaya Literatura|Detgiz]] employee [[Vladimir Lebedev (painter)|Vladimir Lebedev]] saw his manuscript. He was very impressed by it, and published four stories ("Beloved Name", "The Great Snake", "The Mistress of the Copper Mountain", and "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#The Manager's Boot-Soles|The Manager's Boot-Soles]]") in the 11th issue of the ''[[Krasnaya Nov]]'' literary magazine (1936).{{cite book|last=Batin|first=Mikhail|title=Pavel Bazhov|year=1976|publisher=Sovremennik|location=Moscow|language=Russian|page=62}} Inspired by the success of the tales, Bazhov continued working on them. The tales "[[Sinyushka's Well]]", "[[Silver Hoof]]", and "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#The Demidov Caftans|The Demidov Caftans]]" were finished even before the publication of the first ''The Malachite Box'' edition.Batin 1983, p. 8. By 1938 the author finished 14 stories.{{cite AV media | people = Liya Kozyreva (director), [[Vladimir Makeranets]] (director of photography), V. Savchuk (screenwriter) | date = 1979 | title = Pavel Petrovich Bazhov. Film-vospominanie |script-title = ru:Павел Петрович Бажов. Фильм-воспоминание | trans-title = Pavel Petrovich Bazhov. A remembrance documentary film | medium = Videotape| language = Russian | url = http://www.net-film.ru/film-40523/ | access-date =8 December 2015 | format =mp4 | publisher =Russian Archive of Documentary Films and Newsreels| location =[[Sverdlovsk Film Studio]]}} Because of Bazhov's tense relationship with the Communist Party, they were published under two different [[pen names]], either under the name "P. Bragin" or simply under his initials "P. B.".{{cite web|url=http://www.rusarchives.ru/publication/publ_2010_N05_03.shtml|title=Документы Центра документации общественных организаций Свердловской области|year=2010|publisher=Otechestvennye Archivy No. 5|language=Russian|accessdate=4 December 2015|location=The Archives of Russia|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6H8TYKQ0Z?url=http://www.rusarchives.ru/publication/publ_2010_N05_03.shtml|archivedate=4 June 2013|df=}} The name of Vasily Hmelinin was usually in the title as well. The first edition of ''The Malachite Box'' was released in several versions. The first copy was presented to the author for his 60th birthday on 28 January 1939. Several test copies were published in January. A special [[deluxe edition]], decorated with malachite, was sent to the [[1939 New York World's Fair]].{{cite journal|last=Rozhdestvenskaya|first=Yelena |year=2005|title=Moemu neizmenno okryljajushhemu redaktoru: vspominaja Pavla Petrovicha Bazhova |script-title = ru:Моему неизменно окрыляющему редактору: вспоминая Павла Петровича Бажова | trans-title =To my always inspiring editor: remembering Pavel Petrovich Bazhov|journal=Ural|location=Yekaterinburg |volume=1|url= http://magazines.russ.ru/ural/2005/1/r16.html|language=Russian}} The mass market edition published in autumn of the same year. The book was an instant success. It has been republished many times. Overall, twenty three editions of the stories were released from 1941 to 1945.{{cite journal|last=Cherepov|first=Vladimir|year=2004|title=P.P. Bazhov i khudozhestvennaja kultura Sverdlovska 1941–1945 godov |script-title = ru:П.П. Бажов и художественная культура Свердловска 1941–1945 годов | trans-title =P. P. Bazhov and the art of Sverdlovsk in 1941–1945|journal=Ural|location=Yekaterinburg |volume=1|url=http://magazines.russ.ru/ural/2004/1/cherep6.html|language=Russian}} The second edition of the collection was released by the Moscow publishing house [[Sovetsky Pisatel]] in 1942. The book was awarded the [[Stalin prize]].{{cite book|author1=Hilary Chung|author2=Michael Falchikov|title=In the party spirit: socialist realism and literary practice in the Soviet Union, East Germany and China|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dEgowpmwVb0C&pg=PA116|year=1996|publisher=Rodopi|isbn=978-90-5183-979-1|page=116}} The third edition of ''The Malachite Box'' was released by [[Goslitizdat]] in 1944; the fourth by Sverdlovsk Publishing House in 1944; the fifth edition by Sovetsky Pisatel in 1947; the sixth by Goslitizdat in 1948; the seventh by Sverdlovsk Publishing House in 1949. The eighth was the last edition of ''The Malachite Box'' to be published during Bazhov's lifetime in 1950. In 1950 his decaying eyesight made the writing difficult. The last story "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#Zhabrei's Path|Zhabrei's Path]]" was published after his death. According to the All-Union Book Chamber's data as of 1 January 1981, the books in the Soviet Union were republished 253 times with a total circulation of about 37 million copies. ''The Malachite Box'' has been republished many times since then.{{cite web|url=http://fantlab.ru/work87502|title=The Malachite Box|publisher=[[FantLab]]|language=Russian|accessdate=6 December 2015}} === Translations === [[File:La fleur de pierre (Paul Bajov).jpg|thumb|The cover of the 1947 French edition of ''The Malachite Box''.]] The tales were translated into 64 languages, more than 250 editions in foreign languages were released. The list of languages include English, [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], [[Serbo-Croatian]], [[Mongolian language|Mongolian]], [[Chinese language|Chinese]], [[Japanese language|Japanese]], [[Assamese language|Assamese]], [[Kannada]].{{cite journal|last=Lukyanin|first=Valentin |year=2012|title=Bazhov za 99 let: podarok budushhim issledovateljam |script-title = ru:Бажов за 99 лет: подарок будущим исследователям | trans-title =Bazhov in 99 years: a gift for the future scholars|journal=Ural|location=Yekaterinburg |volume=6|url= http://magazines.russ.ru/ural/2012/6/lu13.html|language=Russian}} Four stories from ''The Malachite Box'' were published in the 1943 Moscow magazine ''[[Internatsionalnaya Literatura]]'' in English and French. In 1944 the book was translated from Russian into English by Alan Moray Williams and published by [[Hutchinson (publisher)|Hutchinson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/malachite-casket-tales-from-the-urals/oclc/1998181|title=The malachite casket; tales from the Urals, (Book, 1944)|publisher=[[WorldCat]]|accessdate=30 November 2015}} Bazhov did not know about this translation and found out about it accidentally. In the early 1940s "The Mistress of the Copper Mountain" and "The Stone Flower" were translated into [[Italian language|Italian]]. Bazhov mentioned that he had heard about it from "either folklorist or translator Lesnaya". In the letter as of 25 February 1945 he wrote:
Shortly before the war she told me about the Italian "{{sic|Floro}} di Pietra" ("The Stone Flower") and something like "[[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Madonna]] of the Mountains" ("The Mistress of the Copper Mountain"). It was rather amusing. She promised to give me the book. But did not keep the promise.{{cite web|url=http://kniga.ompural.ru/content.php?main=kniga_life&id=100003|title=The Malachite Box|publisher=The Live Book Museum. Yekaterinburg.|language=Russian|accessdate=22 November 2015 |quote= В Москве есть не то писательница, не то фольклористка или просто переводчица Лесная. Она мне как-то незадолго до войны говорила, что на итальянском вышли «Флоро ди Пиетра» («Каменный цветок») и чуть ли не «Мадонна гор» («Медной горы Хозяйка»). Что-то вовсе забавное. Обещала дать книжку. Но своего обещания не выполнила.}}
Bazhov never saw this book, and even museum workers were unable to locate it. ''The Malachite Box'' in Italian was republished in 1978 by La Scuola as ''Racconti russi, a cura di R. Molteni Grieco'' (lit. "Russian fairy tales, edited by R. Molteni Grieco").{{cite book|editor=Dettori |title=Dalla Sardegna all’Europa. Lingue e letterature regionali: Lingue e letterature regionali|url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=g_fAAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA325&lpg=PA325&dq=Ba%C5%BEov+A+Cura+di+R+Molteni&source=bl&ots=dVjlpt9HUV&sig=MpRF4BzUNSiB62o01HigPK9CJeQ&hl=ru&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjU453m1tvJAhWKpnIKHTOGDVMQ6AEIHjAA#v=onepage&q=Ba%C5%BEov%20A%20Cura%20di%20R%20Molteni&f=false|series=Metodi e prospettive|volume=9|year=2014|publisher=FrancoAngeli|language=Italian|isbn=9788820458485|page=325}} In 1946 the book was translated into [[Bokmål]] and released in Norway by [[Falken Forlag]] (as "Steinblomsten").{{cite web|url=http://www.nb.no/nbsok/nb/9d18c93469e55278fba7c1ea583028d9|title=Steinblomsten|publisher=Nasjonalbiblioteket |language=Norwegian Bokmål|accessdate=25 November 2015}} Several stories were translated into Chinese and published in the [[Shanghai]] literary magazine in 1946. In 1947 it was released in French as "La Fleur de pierre", published by Editions du Bateau Ivre.{{cite web|url=http://www.abebooks.co.uk/fleur-pierre-Bajov-Paul-Editions-Bateau/12495062070/bd|title=La fleur de pierre by Bajov Paul: Editions du Bateau Ivre|publisher=[[AbeBooks]]|accessdate=25 November 2015}} Another English translation was made in the 1950s by Eve Manning.{{cite web|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/10681657|title=Malachite casket : tales from the Urals / P. Bazhov ; [translated from the Russian by Eve Manning; illustrated by O. Korovin ; designed by A. Vlasova]|publisher=The [[National Library of Australia]]|accessdate=25 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/malachite-casket-tales-from-the-urals/oclc/10874080|title=Malachite casket; tales from the Urals. (Book, 1950s)|publisher=[[WorldCat]]|accessdate=30 November 2015}} In all, the stories have been published in English at least four times. Bazhov was very interested in the translations. He called them "the walks in alien places". He was also concerned about the ideological aspects of his work and the possible changes that could happen in translation. He helped translators when he could, explaining the meaning of some Ural [[colloquialism]]s. === Illustrations === The first edition of the collection was illustrated by Alexander Kudrin.{{cite web|url=http://www.oblgazeta.ru/culture/23187/|title= Kniga-sudba: Malakhitovaja shkatulka|script-title = ru:Книга-судьба: Малахитовая шкатулка|last= Filbert|first=Emiliya|date=30 April 2015|publisher=Oblastnaya Gazeta|language=Russian|accessdate=14 December 2015}} Bazhov favored the second edition, released by Sovetsky Pisatel in 1942, because of the illustrations created by Konstantin Kuznetsov. However he criticized Kuznetsov for depicting Silver Hoof as a [[domestic goat]], and was generally extremely demanding when it came to details. On another occasion he was disappointed with the picture of Danilo the Craftsman in [[bast shoe]]s, because miners did not wear them.{{cite journal|last=Cherepov|first=Vladimir|year=2003|title=Podarok P.P. Bazhovu |script-title = ru:Подарок П.П. Бажову | trans-title =A present for P.P. Bazhov|journal=Ural|location=Yekaterinbyrg |volume=2|url=http://magazines.russ.ru/ural/2003/2/cher.html|language=Russian}} Among the other illustrators he liked Oleg Korovin, Yekaterina Gilyova and Vasiliy Bayuskin. == The question of authorship == In ''Prerevolutionary Folklore of the Urals'' Bazhov was noted as the one who collected the texts, yet in the ''Krasnaya Nov'' magazine he was listed as their original author.Balina 2013, p. 264. The question of [[author]]ship arose soon after the publication. Some critics considered the stories pure folklore, others thought of it was a literary work penned by Bazhov. Unfortunately the Soviet [[folkloristics]] was underdeveloped, at that time there were no specific criteria of distinguishing literature from folklore. The question of authorship arose every time a new story was released, and is still discussed nowadays.{{cite journal|last=Blinov|first=Vladimir |year=2012|title=Vse ob uralskom skazitele; P.S. Obretaja sobesednika |script-title = ru:Все об уральском сказителе; P.S. Обретая собеседника | trans-title =All about the Ural storyteller; P.S. Finding the interlocutor|journal=Ural|location=Yekaterinburg |volume=6|url= http://magazines.russ.ru/ural/2008/1/bl35.html|language=Russian}} Before the stories were released as a single volume on 28 January 1939, the issue became urgent. The publisher was concerned with the title of the book and the author's name. It was suggested to release the book as ''The Tales from Grandpa Slyshko'' ({{lang-rus|Сказы дедушки Слышко|Skazy dedushki Slyshko|links=no}}),Batin 1983, p. 6. as if Vasily Hmelinin was the author.{{cite book|last=Galkin|first=Yury |title=Slova i gody: razmyshlenija o zhizni i literature|script-title = ru:Слова и годы: размышления о жизни и литературе |trans-title = Words and years: reflections about life and literature |date= 1989|publisher=Sovremennik|language=Russian|url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=l60jAAAAMAAJ&q=%D0%92%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B9+%D0%90%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87+%D0%A5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD&dq=%D0%92%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B9+%D0%90%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87+%D0%A5%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BD&hl=ru&sa=X&redir_esc=y|page=193}} It was eventually published as ''The Malachite Box''. Bazhov was not certain of the authorship himself.Kruglova, T. "''Bazhov i socialisticheskij realizm'' Бажов и социалистический реализм [Bazhov and [[socialist realism]]]" in: ''P. P. Bazhov i socialisticheskij realizm.'' He tried to avoid the question, joking that "questions such as these should be left to scholars". He admitted that he was writing the tales from memory, and could not possibly recall and write down all the details. Bazhov said he only remembered the main plot elements and some particularly memorable details.Batin 1983, p. 4. The author even claimed that his "reconstruction" eradicated from the stories any possible value for the folklorists. However this position was disputed by the scholars, such as Lyudmila Skorino, Alexander Barmin and others. Nowadays Bazhov's tales are generally accepted as his own "literary work based on the Urals folklore" or call them "transitional" between folklore and fairy tales.Budur 2005, p. 34. There are several reasons for that. Firstly, although the plots of the folk tales remain unchanged, the book conveys certain ideological concepts common for that time period, while folklore normally has no philosophy. Secondly, the manuscripts demonstrate that a huge amount of professional work were done on the [[Composition (visual arts)|composition]], [[imagery]], and language. Bazhov had worked on some stories, such as "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#The Blue Snake|The Blue Snake]]", for years before publication.Bazhov 1952 (1), p. 247. In some cases he created the storylines from scratch, e. g. with "Silver Hoof" he only heard about the mythical creature itself.Batin 1983, p. 5. Later studies showed that he used vague folkloric beliefs and molded then into an original mythology. When asked whether his early stories were closer to folklore sources, Bazhov agreed. As time went by, he became less depended on the folklore and more independent as a writer. The current consensus among the folklore specialists is that he used the fragments of legends and bound them together by his own creative imagination.Lipovetsky 2014, p. 213.{{cite journal|last=Slobozhaninova|first=Lidiya |year=2004|title=Malahitovaja shkatulka Bazhova vchera i segodnja |script-title = ru:“Малахитовая шкатулка” Бажова вчера и сегодня | trans-title =Bazhov's Malachite Box yesterday and today|journal=Ural|location=Yekaterinburg |volume=1|url= http://magazines.russ.ru/ural/2004/1/slob8.html|language=Russian}} == Contents == The first edition of ''The Malachite Box'' was released on 28 January 1939. It consisted of an introduction titled "The Watchhouse on Dumna Mountain" and 14 stories,{{cite web|url=http://kniga.ompural.ru/content.php?main=kniga_life&id=100003|title=The Malachite Box|publisher=The Live Book Museum. Yekaterinburg.|language=Russian|accessdate=22 November 2015}} based on the oral lore of the [[miner]]s and [[gold prospector]]s.{{cite journal|last=Yermakova|first=G|year=1976|title=Заметки о киноискусстве ''На передовых рубежах'' |trans-title= The Notes about Cinema ''At the Outer Frontiers'' |journal=[[Zvezda (magazine)|Zvezda]]|issue=11|pages=204–205|quote=... сказы Бажова основаны на устных преданиях горнорабочих и старателей, воссоздающих реальную атмосферу того времени.}} After the initial publication, the author continuously added new stories to the collection, such as the so-called "mountain fairy tales" in 1942, ''Stories of Germans'' ({{lang-rus|Сказы о немцах|Skazy o nemtsakh|links=no}}) in 1943, a series of stories about Russian [[Steelmaking|steel-makers]] and [[Coining (metalworking)|coiners]] in 1944–1945, ''Stories of Lenin'' ({{lang-rus|Сказы о Ленине|Skazy o Lenine|links=no}}) in 1944–1945, and others.Bazhov 1952 (1), p. 228. Every edition of the collection ended with the dictionary of unusual words and concepts. === Introduction === "The Watchhouse on [[Dumnaya|Dumna Mountain]]" ({{lang-rus|У караулки на Думной горе|U karaulki na Dumnoj gore|links=no}})Bazhov 1944, p. 5. was Bazhov's essay which served as an introduction to the first edition of ''The Malachite Box''.{{cite web|url=http://fantlab.ru/work148151|title=''The Malachite Box'', the 1939 collection|publisher=[[FantLab]]|language=Russian|accessdate=22 November 2015}} It contained some information about the life, industry and culture at the Urals. The first short version of the essay, included in the 1939 book, was titled "The Watchhouse on Dumna Mountain".Bazhov 1952 (2), p. 268. In 1940 the author expanded it and renamed to "By the Old Mine" ({{lang-rus|У старого рудника|U starogo rudnika|links=no}}).Blazhes 2003, p. 10. This version was first published in the 3rd volume of the ''[[Ural (almanac)|Uralsky Sovremennik]]'' almanac (1940). Starting with the 3rd edition of ''The Malachite Box'', this essay was published in all subsequent editions. The author included the essay in every ''The Malachite Box'' edition for the purpose of familiarizing the reader with the unique culture of the Ural region.{{cite web|url=http://fantlab.ru/work87526|title=У старого рудника |trans-title =By the Old Mine |publisher=[[FantLab]]|language=Russian|accessdate=22 November 2015}} === Beloved Name === {{main article|Beloved Name}} "Beloved Name" (alternative translation: That Dear NameBazhov 1950s, p. 9.) describes how the first [[Cossacks]] came to the [[Ural Mountains]] and were faced a tribe of the "Old People" who didn't know the value of gold. The Cossacks decide to take away the lands of the Old People. === The Great Snake === {{main article|The Great Snake}} In this ''skaz'', the old miner's sons meet the Great Serpent (alternative translation: Poloz the Great SnakeBazhov 1944, p. 106.), the master of gold. He appears before them as a man in gold tunic. "His cap was yellow with red flaps on both sides, and his boots were gold too... The earth sank under him where he stood." Bazhov 1950s, p. 147. He shows them how to find [[gold nugget]]s. The story of the brothers is continued in "The Snake Trail" (alternative translation: "The Serpent's Trail"), published in 1939.Bazhov 1944, p. 112.{{cite web|url=http://fantlab.ru/work87278 |title=Змеиный след|trans-title =The Snake Trail|publisher=[[FantLab]]|language=Russian|accessdate=22 November 2015}} === The Mistress of the Copper Mountain === {{main article|The Mistress of the Copper Mountain (fairy tale)}} In this ''skaz'', a young the factory worker Stepan meets the legendary [[The Mistress of the Copper Mountain|Mistress of the Copper Mountain]]. He passes her tests and is rewarded by a [[malachite]] [[casket]] filled with jewellery for his betrothed, Nastyona. === The Malachite Casket === [[File:Stamps of Russia 2004 No 912-914.jpg|thumb|500px|The stamps of Russia, 27 January 2004. The illustrations are (from left to right): "The Stone Flower" (Danilo and [[the Mistress of the Copper Mountain]]), "The Malachite Casket" (the Mistress and Tanyushka), "Golden Hair" (the hunter Ailyp and his ladylove Golden Hair).]] {{main article|The Malachite Casket (fairy tale)}} Stepan dies, leaving the Malachite Casket to his widow Nastyona. Their daughter Tanyushka likes to play with it. With black hair and green eyes, Tanyushka does not look like her mother at all, as if she was born to different parents. When she grows up, she catches the eye of a young [[Russian nobility|noble man]]. She promises to marry him if he shows her the [[Tsarina]] herself at the [[Malachite Room of the Winter Palace|Malachite Room of the Palace]]. === The Stone Flower === {{main article|The Stone Flower}} Danilo the Craftsman hears about a most beautiful Stone Flower grows in the domain of [[the Mistress of the Copper Mountain]]. He goes to the mine and begs the Mistress to show him the Flower. The Mistress warns Danilo that he would never want to go back to his people, but he insists. She then shows him the Malachite Flower. Danilo disappears from the village, leaving his fiancée Katyenka behind. Danilo's story continued in "The Master Craftsman" (alternative translations: "The Mountain Craftsman",Bazhov 1950s, p. 68. "The Mountain Master"{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/russian-magic-tales-from-pushkin-to-platonov/oclc/802293730|title=Russian magic tales from Pushkin to Platonov (Book, 2012)|publisher=[[WorldCat.org]]|accessdate=23 December 2015}}), published a year later in ''[[Na Smenu!]]''. "A Fragile Twig", published in 1940, focuses on Katyenka and Danilo's son. Bazhov had plans for the fourth story,{{cite news|title=The interview with P. Bazhov|date=31 January 1948|work=[[Vechernyaya Moskva]]|publisher=[[Mossovet]]|language=Russian}}: "Собираюсь закончить сказ о "Каменном цветке". Мне хочется показать в нем преемников его героя, Данилы, написать об их замечательном мастерстве, устремлении в будущее. Действие сказа думаю довести до наших дней". but it was never written. === Golden Hair === {{main article|Golden Hair (fairy tale)}} "Golden Hair" is based on the [[Bashkirs]] folklore. It tell the story of a Bashkir hunter Ailyp who meets the daughter of Poloz the Great Snake. ===Other tales and later additions=== {{main article|List of stories within The Malachite Box}} In addition to the stories mentioned above, the first edition of ''The Malachite Box'' contained the following 8 stories: "The Manager's Boot-Soles", "Sochen and His Stones", "Marko's Hill", "The Twisted Roll", "The Two Lizards", "The Cat's Ears", "The Master Craftsman", and "The Snake Trail". The first publication's structure was determined by Bazhov. He preferred to start with the stories about gold and gold prospectors, because the believed this legends to be of more ancient origin.Prikazchikova 2003, p. 12. Later versions of ''The Malachite Box'' contained more than 40 stories.{{cite book|title=Who is Who: 1500 Names|url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=Dd9aONENAxgC&dq|series=Biography|year=2003|publisher=Olma Media Group|isbn=9785812300883|page=82}} == Mythology == Although the tales are based on folkloric tradition, many are somewhat different from their mythological and folkloric roots. Studies show that in many cases Pavel Bazhov used popular beliefs and molded them into his own original mythology. Bazhov said that his early tales, such as "Beloved Name", followed the oral tradition more closely than the later ones. He believed that the stories about the [[Gumyoshevsky mine]] were the closest to the original folklore. He said: "In my opinion, they represent the attempt to reconstruct the folklore of this mine".Mironov, A. "''Obraz Hozjajki Mednoj gory v skazah P. P. Bazhova'' Образ Хозяйки Медной горы в сказах П. П. Бажова [The character of the Mistress of the Copper Mountain in P. P. Bazhov's tales]" in: ''P. P. Bazhov i socialisticheskij realizm.'' As time went by, Bazhov became less depended on the folklore and more independent as a writer. Some characters did not no exist at all in the original Ural folk tradition, although the author constructed them according to the mythological "canon".Shvabauer 2009, p. 119. Pavel Bazhov theorized that most of the existing mythical creatures were created by the populace to explain various unexplained natural phenomena,Bazhov 1952 (1), p. 245. as they are related to some aspects of miners' life. Giving as example, the Earth Cat from "Cat's Ears" is described as "two blue flames that look like cat's ears" above the ground and represents [[Sulfur dioxide|sulfur dioxide gas]].{{cite book|last=Skorino|first=Lyudmila|title=Pavel Petrovitch Bazhov|url=https://books.google.ru/books/about/%D0%9F%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BB_%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87_%D0%91%D0%B0%D0%B6%D0%BE%D0%B2.html?hl=ru&id=-m_YAAAAMAAJ|year=1947|publisher=Sovetsky Pisatel|language=Russian|pages=62–63|chapter=Letter as of September 18, 1945}}Bazhov 1952 (1), p. 244–245. The [[antler]]ed "goat" Silver Hoof from the story of the same name explained the occurrence of [[Peridot|chrysolite]]: "... people often found stones in the glade where the goat had run about. Most of them were green ones, chrysolites, folks call them."Bazhov 1950s, p. 231. The blue snake from the story of the same name represents a [[gold nugget]]. Although speaking about the blue snake was a bad omen among the local miners, to see one was a good sign, and it meant that a person would find a gold nugget.Shvabauer 2003, p. 27. The [[crone]] Sinyushka from the tale "Sinyushka's Well" represents [[marsh gas]], which was actually called "sinyushka" at the Urals. The author noted that supernatural played a bigger part in the miners' lore than in the lore of [[charcoal]] burners or [[blast furnace]] workers. Mining and [[mine exploration]] in particular were always connected with some supernatural forces which presumably helped the workers. Even as late as the 19th century, people used to say about the lucky workers that they "knew the words" and had certain helpers.{{cite book|last=Blazhes|first=Valentin|authorlink=Valentin Blazhes|title=Satira i jumor v dorevoljutsionnom folklore rabochih Urala |script-title = ru:Сатира и юмор в дореволюционном фольклоре рабочих Урала | trans-title = Satire and humour in the prerevolutionary folklore of the Urals workers|url=http://elar.urfu.ru/handle/10995/19851|year=1987|publisher=The [[Ural State University]]|location=Sverdlovsk|language=Russian|pages=30}} The geography is well known because it is specified in the stories. Bazhov mentions real locations such as [[Sysert]], the [[Polevskoy Copper Smelting Plant]], the Gumyoshevsky mine, the villages [[Kosoy Brod]] and Krasnogorka, the Ryabinovka river. Mythical creatures in ''The Malachite Box'' are either [[anthropomorphous]] (primarily femaleKharitonova, E. "''Tipologija zhenskih obrazov v skazah P. P. Bazhova'' Типология женских образов в сказах П. П. Бажова [Classification of female characters in P. P. Bazhov's skazy]" in: ''P. P. Bazhov i socialisticheskij realizm.'') or [[zoomorphic]]. The animals that appear in the stories and have zoomorphic attributes are lizards, snakes ("[[The Great Snake]]"), cranes ("[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#Dikes of Gold|Dikes of Gold]]"), ants ("Zhabrei's Path"), swans ("[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#Yermak's Swans|Yermak's Swans]]"), cats, the deer. All these creatures, with the exception of the cats, were depicted on the [[Permian bronze casts]] (the 5-15 centuries). Archaeologies had found the casts next to [[Mount Azov]] and along the [[Chusovaya River]] in [[Perm Krai]], [[Sverdlovsk Oblast]] and [[Chelyabinsk Oblast]] of Russia.{{cite journal|last=Ivanov|first=Alexei|year=2004 |trans-title = The Ugrian Archetype in the Demonology of Bazhov's Stories |title=Угорский архетип в демонологии сказов Бажова|journal=The Philologist|publisher=The Perm State Humanitarian and Pedagogical University|issue=5|issn=2076-4154|url=http://philolog.pspu.ru/module/magazine/do/mpub_5_90}} As for the cats, Alexei Ivanov noted that they are unlikely to come from the folk tales, and were probably added into the stories by the author. The anthropomorphous creatures are primarily female—[[Azovka]] from "Beloved Name", [[Golden Hair (fairy tale)|Golden Hair]], the blue snake, [[the Mistress of the Copper Mountain]], Poskakushka from "The Fire-Fairy", Sinyushka, Veselukha from "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#Veselukha's Meadow|Veselukha's Meadow]]". They belong to different age groups: Poskakushka is a little girl, Golden Hair and the Mistress are maidens, Veselukha is a young woman, the blue snake is a woman, Sinyushka is an old woman. They mostly contact men, e.g. Poskakushka helps Fedyunka to find gold; the blue snake appears before boys; the Mistress traditionally helps single men only. Bazhov believed that miners missed women, because their work allowed for little contact with them, and therefore so many of their stories had female creatures.{{cite journal|last=Zherdev|first=Denis|year=2003 |title= Binarnost kak element pojetiki bazhovskikh skazov |script-title = ru:Бинарность как элемент поэтики бажовских сказов |journal=Izvestiya of the Ural State University|publisher=The Ural State University|issue=28 |pages=46–57|url= http://elar.urfu.ru/bitstream/10995/24181/1/iurg-2003-28-06.pdf|language=Russian |trans-title = Binarity as the Poetic Element in Bazhov's Skazy}} The recurring characters that appear in folkloric tradition are the Mistress of the Copper Mountain and Poloz the Great Snake. Both of them are keepers of hidden underground riches. The Mistress, described as either a beautiful green-eyed woman in [[malachite]] gown or a [[lizard]] with the crown on her head, is the keeper of gemstones. Poloz is the master of every existing piece of gold. The miners believed that if a gold-bearing [[lode]] disappeared, it meant that the Great Snake moved it to a different place. Bazhov introduced numerous daughters of Poloz, including Golden Hair from the tale of the same name. The relationship between Poloz and the Mistress is unclear. Bazhov commented that he asked some story-tellers about it, but they could not answer the question.{{cite book|last=Bazhov|first=Pavel|title=У старого рудника |trans-title = By the Old Mine|url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=Hmp6b9Ugq2MC&dq|series=The Malachite Casket: Tales from the Urals|date=2014-07-10|publisher=Litres|language=Russian|isbn=9785457073548}} Bazhov believed that the Mistress was one of the latest characters to appear in legends, because of the complexity of the character. The origin of the characters such as those might also be [[Finno-Ugric peoples|Finno-Ugric]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ulc-russia.com/fun/people_talk/item/91/|title=Translations From Pavel Bazhov into English. Part 1|last=Vernikov|first=Alexander|publisher=ULC: Ural Life & Culture|accessdate=23 December 2015}} The Finno-Ugric peoples, who lived in that area, migrated to the [[Baltic Sea]] or assimilated into the new Russian culture, adding to it their folklore. Alexander Vernikov noted:
This lore included mining and metallurgic techniques unknown to Russians. [...] Finno-Ugrians’ beliefs and legends... featured the underground riches and powers, mostly moral and spiritual, impersonated in [[chthonic]] deities.
Poloz the Great Snake, the blue snake, Sinyushka, the Mistress of the Copper Mountain all act like magical helpers and present a threat to mortals at the same time.Lipovetsky 2014, pp. 216–217. The help of such mythical creatures would explain why some miners were luckier than others. They were connected with mountains because of people's the perception of the mountains as "magical space"—the mountain was the source of life, it protected from hostile forces and was the residence of divine patrons.{{cite journal|last=Kulikova|first=E. V|year=2012|title=От литературного табу к Хозяйке Медной горы: деконструкция мифа в прозе В. Маканина |trans-title = From a literary taboo to the Mistress of the Copper Mountain: the myth deconstruction in V. Makanin's prose|script-title= ''Ot literaturnogo tabu k Hozjajke Mednoj gory: dekonstruktsija mifa v proze V. Makanina'' |journal=Molodoy Ucheny|volume=7|issue=42|pages=161–164|issn=2072-0297|url=http://www.moluch.ru/archive/42/5127/|language=Russian}} Yet the creatures such as Sinyushka and the blue snake do not hesitate to kill those who did not pass their tests. Even those who had been rewarded by them rarely live happily ever after. These characters usually die soon.Balina 2013, p. 273. Snakes live underground (according to the legends, in the [[underworld]]) and are traditionally associated with the [[Chthonic]] deities.Shvabauer 2003, p. 24. == Ideological influences == Many scholars highlighted the potently ideological nature of ''The Malachite Box'', especially regarding the stories created at the end of the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Great Patriotic War]] (1941–1945) and in the post-war years. Bazhov's work was supported by the Party. It was in high demand from the very beginning due to the shortage of the "workers' folklore", which should have represented the so-called [[class consciousness]] of the [[proletariat]]. The book conveys certain ideological concepts common for that time period, such as emphasis on the hard life of the working class before the [[Russian Revolution]]. Workers are depicted as the victims of class exploitation, while the mountain spirits are typically presented as magical helpers to the underprivileged.Balina 2013, p. 276. The mythical characters such as Poloz the Great Snake or the Mistress of the Copper Mountain act according to the principles of [[social justice]],Shvabauer 2009, p. 60. e. g. in "The Manager's Boot-Soles" it's said that the Mistress "didn't like it when folks were treated ill underground".Bazhov 1950s, p. 112. Bazhov defines important [[Value (personal and cultural)|values]], such as love, family, [[masculinity]], respect for the elders and workers, skill, sceptical attitude toward religion and [[clergy]], [[diligence]], [[camaraderie]], harmony in the house and friendly relationship with neighbours, [[hospitality]], modesty, honesty.Zubova, N. "''Sobiratelnye obrazy i massovye sceny bazhovskih skazov'' Собирательные образы и массовые сцены бажовских сказов [Zubova N. P. Collective characters and mass scenes in Bazhov's skazy]" in: ''P. P. Bazhov i socialisticheskij realizm.'' An ideal man is a "simple soul", who is brave, patient, and hard-working. An ideal woman is beautiful, hard-working, loyal, thrifty, she takes care of household and children, gets on well with her husband. The plots often dramatize class conflicts.Balina 2005, p. 114. Some revolutionary [[propaganda]] is present in the dialogues. The narrator constantly refers to the fact that life before the Revolution was harder for working people. [[Mariya Litovskaya]] compared Pavel Bazhov to [[Mikhail Bulgakov]], [[Andrei Platonov]], and [[Dmitri Kedrin]] in such a way that the characters represent two concepts: the person who puts spiritual above the material, who looks for the truth, but loses a fight with nature in the end; and the new Soviet idea of protagonist as a professional who is ready for change and is capable of remaking the world. Foreigners are shown as uninspired people without creative spark, e.g. the German from "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#Ivanko Krylatko|Ivanko Krylatko]]".Bazhov 1952 (1), p. 230. In the stories penned during and after the Great Patriotic War, Bazhov wrote about great positive changes that happened in the life of the Ural workers after the [[October Revolution]].Bazhov 1952 (2), p. 257. A series of stories was devoted to the Russian communist leaders, [[Vladimir Lenin]] and [[Joseph Stalin]]. Bazhov shared popular in the Soviet [[historiography]] [[anti-capitalism|anti-capitalist]] attitude. The owners of the Ural plants were depicted as worthless, idle, greedy and cruel. He criticized or parodied the Ural businessmen [[Alexei Turchaninov]], [[Pavel Solomirsky]] and [[Dmitry Solomirsky]]. Critics didn't originally consider the texts suitable for children's reading because of their difficult multilayered language, but the ideological pressure caused them to be actively used for [[Education in the Soviet Union|children's education at the Urals]].Litovskaya 2014, p. 247. Children were to "listen to the deeply rooted folk tales told by wise men and to follow the examples of the protagonists that these wise men presented".{{cite book|last=Shen|first=Qinna |title=The Politics of Magic: DEFA Fairy-Tale Films|url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=14e8CQAAQBAJ&pg=PA51&lpg=PA51&dq=bazhov+The+Stone+Craftsman&source=bl&ots=skQGku086J&sig=7uo5fQAd_g0m5qcdqJUamun69Kc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiX3ovbvKfJAhWLXSwKHbPABSEQ6AEIKzAD#v=onepage&q=bazhov%20The%20Stone%20Craftsman&f=false|series=Series in Fairy-Tale Studies|date=2015-06-15|publisher=Wayne State University Press|isbn=0814339042|page=51}} Mariya Litovskaya commented that the so-called "child-toned" stories were simplified and shortened so that even the unskilled reader could easily read each of them in one go. In such stories the children are the main characters and the mythical creatures do not threaten them, but instead help them, which compensated "for the inadequacy of the social and family help" and helped to create "favourable living conditions" for the children, therefore promoting a positive attitude in the young readers. The narrator often reminds the reader that even such magical help is no longer necessary, because the Soviet society has righted all the wrongs of a fairy-tale reality.Balina 2005, p. 116. Tatiana Kruglova comments that there is a clear split of characters based on their [[social class]]: there are working men, most often depicted as positive characters, and their masters, shown critically or ironically. But in the pre-war stories the class criteria existed as the background only. The conflict between the characters came from the collision between poetic and pragmatical, grand and common, irrational and rational. == Reception and legacy == ''The Malachite Box'' and its author became enormously popular. It was met with significant praise by critics and enthusiastically received by readers,Batin 1983, p. 3. including the general populace and the more sophisticated Soviet [[intelligentsia]].Balina 2013, p. 263. Bazhov turned into one of the most famous writers in the Soviet Union. Strangers would greet him on the streets. The critics agreed that "never has the labour of miners, stone-cutters, teemers been celebrate in such a way, neither in verses, nor in prose", and that Bazhov managed to show the essence of the professional skill of the miners. Mikhail Batin complimented its uniqueness, and novelty in the contents and in the form. Favourable reviews on ''The Malachite Box'' appeared in ''Uralsky Rabochy'' (18 January 1939), ''[[Izvestia]]'' (4 April), ''[[Pravda]]'' and ''Industria Sotsialisma'' (July). However the critics disagreed on the question of authorship. Some considered ''The Malachite Box'' pure folklore, others thought of it was a literary work penned by Bazhov. The author himself tried to avoid the issue, joking that "questions such as these should be left to scholars". At present Bazhov's tales are generally accepted as his own literary work based on the Urals folklore. The editor of ''Izvestia'' called ''The Malachite Box'' "a valuable contribution to the Soviet fiction" and noted that "the vividness of expression and poetic richness turn the wonderful stories of P. P. Bazhov into the truly artistic, poetic works of art". [[David Zaslavsky]] in ''Pravda'' called the book "remarkable", the imagery "sharp", and commented that the ''skazy'' are "excellent short stories that uncover the Urals history". [[Demyan Bedny]] wrote about it: "The richness of the ''skazy'' plots, the variety and beauty of their imagery are stunning. How many wonderful sources are there for [[Wood carving|woodcutters]] and artists, for drama, opera and ballet, not to mention cinema!" Marina Balina wrote that Bazhov had "managed to present the prerevolutionary Urals as a mythological world with mountain spirits and dark forces controlling the hidden riches". The stories, characters, [[Style (literature)|style]],Eydinova 2003, p. 40. the combination of fantasy and realism, and the language were praised.Eydinova 2003, p. 41. Bazhov was congratulated as a great storyteller, his stories were praised as having "huge ethic, aesthetic, and educational potential".{{cite journal|last=Blazhes|first=Valentin |authorlink=Valentin Blazhes |year=2004|title=К 125-летию со дня рождения П. П. Бажова |trans-title= To the 125 anniversary since the birth of P. P. Bazhov|journal=Izvestiya of the Ural State University|publisher=The [[Ural State University]]|issue=31|pages=289–292|url=http://elar.urfu.ru/handle/10995/23844|language=Russian}} [[Anna Karavayeva]] mentioned that "such books enrich not just our folklore, but the Soviet literature as a whole". Elena Givental wrote that the author "created the most poetic and identifiable set of Urals stories", which "has left a strong imprint in the minds of the Russian people".{{cite journal|last=Givental|first=Elena|date=14 April 2013|title=Three Hundred Years of Glory and Gloom. The Urals Region of Russia in Art and Reality|journal=SAGE Open|publisher=SAGE Journals|volume=3|issue=2|doi=10.1177/2158244013486657|url=http://sgo.sagepub.com/content/3/2/2158244013486657}} The article in ''[[Pravda]]'' as of 20 March 1943 stated that "Our [Soviet] people have fallen in love with the Ural's old storyteller P. Bazhov".Bazhov 1952 (1), p. 242. [[File:Flag of Polevskoy.svg|thumb|The flag of [[Polevskoy]] ''(from left to right)'': the [[Venus symbol]] (♀), which represents the chemical element [[copper]] and was the brand of the [[Polevskoy Copper Smelting Plant]], the Mistress of the Copper Mountain depicted as the golden lizard, the symbolic representation of the Stone Flower [[The Stone Flower|from the story of the same name]], and the [[Octagram|eight-pointed]] [[Star (heraldry)|star]], the brand of the [[Seversky Pipe Plant]].]] Selected stories have been a part of school core [[curriculum]] since the Soviet Union, and are still used for education purposes nowadays.{{cite web|url=http://pedagog.vlsu.ru/fileadmin/Dep_pedagogical/fradkin2013/Izmailova.pdf|title=Сказ П.П. Бажова "Хрупкая веточка" в курсе "Русская народная педагогика" |trans-title =P. Bazhov's skaz ''A Fragile Twig'' in the course ''The Russian Folk Pedagogics''|last=Izmaylova|first=A. B|publisher=The [[Vladimir State University]]|language=Russian|accessdate=11 December 2015}} The [[Ministry of Education and Science (Russia)|Ministry of Education and Science of Russia]] included the tales in their 2013 list of ''100 Recommended Books'' for schoolchildren.{{cite web|url=http://cdnimg.rg.ru/pril/article/73/04/52/Spisok_100_knig.pdf|title=100 books recommended by the Ministry of Education and Science of Russia for the home-reading of schoolchildren|date=16 January 2013|publisher=[[Rossiyskaya Gazeta]]|language=Russian|accessdate=24 December 2015}} Their effective pedagogical influence have been noted.{{cite web|url=http://pedagog.vlsu.ru/fileadmin/Dep_pedagogical/Lerner2013/Izmailova__A.B._-_statja.pdf|title=Сказ П.П. Бажова "Приказчиковы подошвы" в курсе "Русская народная педагогика" |trans-title =P. Bazhov's skaz ''The Manager's Boot-Soles'' in the course ''The Russian Folk Pedagogics''|last=Izmaylova|first=A. B|publisher=The [[Vladimir State University]]|language=Russian|accessdate=11 December 2015}} ''The Malachite Box'' became a classic of Soviet children's literature, yet the stories continued to be popular among adults as well. Mark Lipovetsky believed the situation in the author's life added to the depth of the tales and made them so popular among the adult readers.Lipovetsky 2014, p. 215. They were exceptionally popular during the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Great Patriotic War]]. The [[paperback]]s were sent to the [[front line]]. The author received [[fan mail]] from the soldiers who asked to send them the book. The publication attracted a large number of [[Folkloristics|folklorists]], who collected tales near Sysert since 1940s and long after Pavel Bazhov's death.Blazhes 1983, p. 5. The characters of the Ural Mountains folklore such as [[the Mistress of the Copper Mountain]] became very well known after their appearance in Bazhov's ''The Malachite Box''.Blazhes 1983, p. 9.{{cite journal|last=Meshcherova|first=K.| author2=Gerasimova A.|date=20 June 2014|title=Легенды и мифы Урала глазами художников|journal=Materials Collection of the 5th International Scientific Conference|publisher=Scientific center Aksioma |trans-title = Legends and Myths of the Urals by the Eyes of the Artists|issue=''Nauchnye diskussii o tsennostjah sovremennogo obshhestva'' [Научные дискуссии о ценностях современного общества], lit. "Scientific discussions about values of modern society" |language=Russian |pages=32–33}} [[Sysert]]'s old coat of arms (1982–2002) featured the Mistress as a lizard with a crown,{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldicum.ru/russia/subjects/towns/sysert.htm|title=Сысертский городской округ |trans-title=Sysert Town District, Sverdlovsk Oblast|work=Coats of arms of Russia|publisher=Heraldicum.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=9 December 2015}} as did Yekaterinburg's coat of arms from 1973 to 1991.{{cite web|url= http://www.heraldicum.ru/russia/subjects/towns/ekatburg.htm|title= Городской округ г. Екатеринбург (Cвердловская область) |trans-title=Yekaterinburg City District Yekaterinburg, Sverdlovsk Oblast|work=Coats of arms of Russia|publisher=Heraldicum.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=9 December 2015}} The early design of [[Polevskoy]]'s coat of arms (1981) had an image of the Stone Flower.{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldicum.ru/russia/subjects/towns/polevoj.htm|title= Городской округ г. Полевской, Свердловская область |trans-title=Polevskoy Urban District, Sverdlovsk Oblast|work=Coats of arms of Russia|publisher=Heraldicum.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=9 December 2015}} The current version, as well as the flag of the town, features the Mistress depicted as the golden lizard. The Malachite Casket became the symbol of the Urals.Nikulina 2003, p. 76. ''The Malachite Box'' is constantly republished, commented and illustrated. Not all stories are equally popular nowadays. The most popular tales were written between 1936 and 1939. Among the later stories, "A Fragile Twig" (1940), "[[The Fire-Fairy]]" (1940),Budur 2005, p. 35. "Tayutka's Mirror" (1941), "Ivanko Krylatko" (1943),Bazhov 1952 (2), p. 265. "[[That Spark of Life]]" (1943)Bazhov 1952 (2), p. 262. were popular. As for the skazy about Vladimir Lenin, such as "The Bogatyr's Glove" (1944) and "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#The Sunstone|The Sunstone]]", they were called excessively [[didactic]], and "remain known to avid Bazhov experts only".Balina 2013, p. 265. Some Bazhov's stories on the present day topics were unsuccessful even among his contemporaries. [[Mariya Litovskaya]] criticized the author for "yielding to social pressure" and adapting the folk tales of the Ural region for children.Litovskaya 2014, p. 243. === Critical history=== The tales have been a popular subject for analysis. During Soviet times, every edition of ''The Malachite Box'' had a [[foreword]] written by a famous writer or scholar, commenting on the creativity of the Ural miners, cruel landlords, social oppression and the "great workers unbroken by the centuries of slavery". The critics claimed that the author's purpose was to "glorify" the working class. [[Sergey Narovchatov]] in the 1979 article said that "the Ural worker in Bazhov's stories, who represents Russian [[proletariat]], rises up in all his giant stature. It is mighty, talented, creatively gifted". After the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], with the change of the public's ideology, the stories were regarded as Bazhov's way to run away from the "harsh reality of Soviet period".{{cite AV media | people = Yury Malyugin (director), Sergey Kazakov (director of photography), Oksana Shaparova (screenwriter) | date = 2010 | title = Sovetskij skaz Pavla Bazhova |script-title = ru:Советский сказ Павла Бажова | trans-title = The Soviet skaz of Pavel Bazhov | medium = Television production| language = Russian | url = http://tvkultura.ru/brand/show/brand_id/23025| access-date =8 December 2015 | publisher =[[Russia-K]]}} The scholars changed their focus to other issues, such as beauty and ugliness, life and death,Nikulina 2003, p. 80. order and [[Randomness|chaos]], [[eroticism]], the relationship of people with nature and the Mountain, the mysterious in general,Nikulina 2003, p. 77. the place of the person in the world. Lidiya Slobozhaninova summarizes that some parts of ''The Malachite Box'' "become outdated, but others gain new meaning". === Adaptations === The stories from the collection inspired numerous adaptations, including films, radio{{cite web|url=http://genome.ch.bbc.co.uk/438285b18885489ba9d3c545d0ace74b|title=CHILDREN'S HOUR - BBC Home Service Basic - 27 July 1945|publisher=[[BBC Genome Project]]|accessdate=9 December 2015}} and stage adaptations. The Soviet poet [[Demyan Bedny]] was so impressed with the tales that he decided to adapt them into poetry. He began the work on 27 June 1939 and adapted the 14 original stories by 1 October 1939.Vasilyev, I. "''Demjan Bednyj i P. P. Bazhov'' Демьян Бедный и П. П. Бажов [Demyan Bedny and P. P. Bazhov]" in: ''P. P. Bazhov i socialisticheskij realizm.'' He titled the manuscript ''Gornaya poroda'' ({{lang-rus|Горная порода|links=no}}, lit. "[[Rock (geology)|Rock]]"). Bedny made some changes to the length of some scenes, changed the character names, the endings, the dialogues, and the titles of several stories, e.g. "The Great Snake" was called "Brothers", "The Manager's Boot-Soles" was called "As Deserved". He started to prepare it for publication, but his plans were hindered when he saw Bazhov's new stories. Bedny was not happy with them and abandoned the book. It was published after his death in 1959, and is not well known now. On 10 May 1939 the art committee under the [[Council of People's Commissars]] decided to organize a parade of all children's theatres, and Bazhov was asked to write a play based on ''The Malachite Box''. They play was finished on 11 August and was performed at the [[Yekaterinburg Municipal Youth Theatre|Sverdlovsk Youth Theatre]] the same year.Litovskaya 2014, p. 249. Following the success of the play, the Sverdlovsk Youth Theatre staged children's plays ''Yermak's Swans'' in 1942 and ''Silver Hoof'' in 1947, both written by the Soviet playwright [[Evgeny Permyak]].Bazhov 1952 (1), p. 248.Bazhov 1952 (1), p. 249. The [[Moscow Puppet Theater]] staged a 1947 play ''Tales from the Urals'' ({{lang-rus|Сказы старого Урала|Skazy starogo Urala|links=no}}) by Klavdiya Filippova, based on "Sinyushka's Well" and "[[Golden Hair (fairy tale)|Golden Hair]]". Filippova then combined "The Great Snake" and "The Snake Trail" to create ''Poloz's Daughter'' ({{lang-rus|Полозова дочка|Polozova dochka|links=no}}) and "The Stone Flower" with "The Master Craftsman" to create the children's play ''The Stone Flower''.Litovskaya 2014, p. 250. All these plays were published in the 1949 collection ''Plays for Children's Theatre Based on Bazhov's Stories'' was published in Sverdlovsk. The storied that were considered difficult for a young reader were even more simplified as their stage adaptations, e.g. the sad ending of "Sinyushka's Well" was changed to a happy one, and Pavel Bazhov was not opposed to the changes.Litovskaya 2014, p. 252.Litovskaya 2014, p. 251. In 1941 [[Alexander Fridlender]] composed the ballet ''The Mountain Fairy Tale'' ({{lang-rus|Горная сказка|Gornaja skazka|links=no}}), based on "[[The Mistress of the Copper Mountain (fairy tale)|The Mistress of the Copper Mountain]]".{{cite web|url=http://sokomso.ru/members/fridlender-aleksandr-grigorevich|title=Фридлендер Александр Григорьевич |trans-title = Fridlender Alexander Grigoryevitch|publisher=The Union of Composers of Sverdlovsk Oblast|language=Russian|accessdate=20 December 2015}} Based on "Marko's Hill", [[Klara Katsman]] created the [[operetta]] ''Mark Beregovik'' ({{lang-rus|Марк Береговик|links=no}}), which premiered in Sverdlovsk in 1955. Lyubov Nikolskaya composed the children's opera ''Silver Hoof'' based on the story of the same name in 1959.{{cite web|url=http://sokomso.ru/members/nikolskaya-lyubov-borisovna|title=Nikolskaya Lyubov Borisovna|publisher=The Union of Sverdlovsk Oblast Composers|language=Russian|accessdate=21 December 2015}} [[Vladimir Goryachikh]] composed the ballet ''The Living Stone'' ({{lang-rus|Живой камень|Zhivoj kamen|links=no}}) based on "Sinyushka's Well", which premiered in [[Nizhny Tagil]] in 1965.Sokolskaya, Zh. "''P. P. Bazhov i muzyka Urala'' П. П. Бажов и музыка Урала [Pavel Bazhov and the Ural music]" in: ''P. P. Bazhov i socialisticheskij realizm.'' The 1973 opera ''The Fire Maid'' (based on "The Fire-Fairy") for schools was composed by Robert Long, with story adapted and lyrics by Dorothy Gulliver{{cite web|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/20842176?q&sort=holdings+desc&_=1450873691571&versionId=24747844|title=The Fire maid [music] : an opera for schools / music by Robert Long ; story adapted and lyrics by Dorothy Gulliver from a story in "The Malachite Casket" by Pavel Petrovich Bazhov|publisher=[[Trove]]|accessdate=23 December 2015}} The 2012 opera ''The Malachite Casket'', based on "The Mistress of the Copper Mountain" and "The Malachite Casket", was created by [[Dmitry Batin]].{{cite web|url=http://permopera.ru/playbills/repertoire/show/19|title=Малахитовая шкатулка |trans-title = The Malachite Casket|publisher=[[Perm Opera and Ballet Theatre|The Perm Tchaikovsky Opera and Ballet Theatre]]|language=Russian|accessdate=15 December 2015}} Two [[filmstrip]]s were released, ''The Fire-Fairy'' (1956) and ''The Malachite Box'' (1972). "The Stone Flower" was adapted for stage many times. The first [[The Stone Flower (Fridlender)|ballet of the same name]] was created by Alexander Fridlender in 1944.{{cite web|url=http://fantlab.ru/work87497 |title=Каменный цветок |trans-title=The Stone Flower|publisher=[[FantLab]]|language=Russian|accessdate=22 November 2015}} The [[opera]] in four acts ''The Stone Flower'' by [[Kirill Molchanov]] premiered on 10 December 1950 in Moscow at the [[Stanislavski and Nemirovich-Danchenko Music Theatre]].Bazhov 1952, p. 243.{{cite web|url=http://www.belcanto.ru/zvetok.html|title=Опера Молчанова "Каменный цветок" |trans-title = Molchanov's opera ''The Stone Flower''|publisher=Belcanto.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=20 December 2015}} [[Sergey Severtsev]] wrote the Russian language [[libretto]]. It was the first opera of Molchanov.{{cite book|last=Rollberg|first=Peter |title=Historical Dictionary of Russian and Soviet Cinema|url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=Cuw1vHuxITYC|date=November 7, 2008|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9780810862685|page=461}} The role of Danila ([[tenor]]) was sung by [[Mechislav Shchavinsky]], [[Larisa Adveyeva]] sung [[the Mistress of the Copper Mountain]] ([[mezzo-soprano]]), Dina Potapovskaya sung Katya ([[coloratura soprano]]).{{cite book|editors=The [[Union of the Soviet Composers]]|title=Советская музыка | trans-title = Soviet Music|url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=ic8SAAAAIAAJ|volume=1-6|year=1950|publisher=Государственное Музыкальное издательство|language=Russian|page=109}}{{cite journal|last=Medvedev|first=A|date=February 1951|title=Каменный цветок | trans-title = The Stone Flower|journal=Smena|publisher=Smena Publishing House|volume=2|issue=570|url=http://smena-online.ru/node/43595/print|language=Russian}} The 1954 ballet ''[[The Tale of the Stone Flower (Prokofiev)|The Tale of the Stone Flower]]'' was created by Sergei Prokofiev. ''Skazy'', also called ''The Stone Flower'', was the 1987 play of the [[Maly Theatre (Moscow)|Maly Theatre]]. ==== Music ==== A lot of Soviet and Russian composers drew inspiration from ''The Malachite Box''. The [[Suite (music)|suite]] ''Skazy'' was created by [[Grigory Frid]] in 1948.{{cite web|url=http://www.sarcons.ru/tl_files/Dis%20Sovet/Zaschita%202015/Romashkov/Tekst%20dissertacii%20Romashkova.pdf|title=Жанровая модель сюиты для оркестра русских народных инструментов|trans-title = The suite genre model for Russian folk orchestra|last=Romashkov|first=Anatoly|year=2015|publisher=[[Saratov Conservatory]] |pages=96, 211|language=Russian|accessdate=4 December 2015}} [[Alexey Muravlev]] based his symphonic poem ''Mount Azov'' (1949) on the tale "Beloved Name".{{cite book|editor=Nikolay Skatov|title=Русская литература 20 века|trans-title = Russian literature of the 20th century|url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=efZ44dFS1eAC&pg=PA152&dq=%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%84%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F+%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%8D%D0%BC%D0%B0+%D0%90%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B2-%D0%93%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0&hl=ru&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%84%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F%20%D0%BF%D0%BE%D1%8D%D0%BC%D0%B0%20%D0%90%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B2-%D0%93%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B0&f=false |year=2005|publisher=OLMA Media Group |language=Russian|isbn=9785948482453|page=152}} In 1979 [[Margarita Kesareva]] created a series of piano pieces ''Ural Book'' (Уральская тетрадь), which included the movement "The Bear Stone" ({{lang-rus|Медведь-камень|Medved-kamen|links=no}}) inspired by "Yermak's Swans".{{cite web|url=http://sokomso.ru/members/kesareva-margarita-aleksandrovna|title=Kesareva Margarita Aleksandrovna|publisher=The Union of Sverdlovsk Oblast Composers|language=Russian|accessdate=21 December 2015}} In 2006 "Sinyushka's Well" was adapted into the musical for Russian folk instruments orchestra by Svetlana Nesterova.{{cite web|url=http://www.compozitor.spb.ru/eng/catalogue_editions/the_regular/index.php?SECTION_ID=1654&ELEMENT_ID=23814|title=Sinyushka's Well. Suite from the musical after P. P. Bazhov's Story of the same name. For Russian folk instruments orchestra. Score|publisher=Compozitor Publishing House|accessdate=30 November 2015|location=Saint Petersburg}} ==== Live action films ==== * ''The Winged Horses'' ({{lang-rus|Крылатые кони|Krylatye koni|links=no}}), a 1945 Soviet film based on "Ivanko Krylatko"{{cite web|url=http://bibliogid.ru/pisateli/o-pisatelyakh/541-bazhov-pavel-petrovich|title=Bazhov Pavel Petrovich: Adaptations|publisher=Bibliogid|language=Russian|accessdate=9 December 2015}} * ''[[The Stone Flower (1946 film)|The Stone Flower]]'', a 1946 Soviet film;{{cite web|url=http://2011.russiancinema.ru/index.php?e_dept_id=2&e_movie_id=2651|title=The Stone Flower (1946)|publisher=The Russian Cinema Encyclopedia|language=Russian|accessdate=23 November 2015}} incorporates plot elements from the stories "[[The Mistress of the Copper Mountain (fairy tale)|The Mistress of the Copper Mountain]]" and "The Master Craftsman". * ''[[Stepan's Remembrance]]'', a 1976 Soviet film, the adaptation of "The Mistress of the Copper Mountain" and "[[The Malachite Casket (fairy tale)|The Malachite Casket]]". * ''Sinyushka's Well'', a 1978 Soviet film made on [[Sverdlovsk Film Studio]] for the 100th anniversary since the birth of Pavel Bazhov.{{cite web|url=http://www.kino-teatr.ru/short/movie/sov/16963/annot|title=Sinyushka's Well 1978|publisher=Kino-Teatr.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=3 December 2015}} * ''The Stone Flower'' (another title: ''Skazy''), a television film of two-episodes that premiered on 1 January 1988. This film is a photoplay (a theatrical play that has been filmed for showing as a film) based on the 1987 play of the [[Maly Theatre (Moscow)|Maly Theatre]]. It was directed by Vitaly Ivanov, with the music composed by [[Nikolai Karetnikov]], and released by [[Studio Ekran]]. It starred [[Yevgeny Samoylov]], Tatyana Lebedeva, [[Tatyana Pankova]], [[Oleg Kutsenko]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kino-teatr.ru/teatr/movie/81199/annot/|title=Каменный цветок 1987 |trans-title= The Stone Flower 1987|publisher=Kino-teatr.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=9 December 2015}} * ''The Secret Power'' ({{lang-rus|Тайная сила|Tainaya sila|links=no}}), a 2001 Russian film{{cite web|url=http://www.e1.ru/news/spool/news_id-297721-section_id-1.html|title=Средний Урал отмечает 130-летие со дня рождения Павла Бажова |trans-title=The central Ural celebrates the 130 anniversary since the birth of Pavel Bazhov|date=27 January 2009|publisher=[[Yekaterinburg]] Online|language=Russian|accessdate=2 December 2015}} * ''[[The Golden Snake]]'', a 2007 Russian film{{cite web|url=http://www.kino-teatr.ru/kino/movie/ros/13738/annot/ |title=Золотой полоз |trans-title=The Great Snake|publisher=Kino-Teatr.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=8 December 2015}} is loosely based on "The Great Snake". * ''[[The Book of Masters]]'', a 2009 Russian language fantasy film, is loosely based on Bazhov's tales, mostly "The Mistress of the Copper Mountain"{{cite web|url=http://newslab.ru/article/291973|title=Книга мастеров |trans-title=The Book of Masters|last=Mezenov|first=Sergey|date=30 October 2009|publisher=Newslab.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=8 December 2015}} and "The Stone Flower".{{cite web|url=http://www.proficinema.ru/distribution/reviews/detail.php?ID=69936|title="Книга мастеров": герои русских сказок в стране Disney |trans-title=''The Book of Masters'': the Russian fairy tale characters in Disneyland |last=Sakharnova|first=Kseniya|date=21 October 2009|publisher=Profcinema Co. Ltd.|language=Russian|accessdate=8 December 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazeta.ru/culture/2009/10/27/a_3277257.shtml|title= Nor have we seen its like before… |trans-title=|last=Zabaluyev|first=Yaroslav|date=27 October 2009|publisher=[[Gazeta.ru]]|language=Russian|accessdate=8 December 2015}} A [[docufiction]] feature film ''Tales of the Ural Mountains'' ({{lang-rus|Сказы уральских гор|Skazy uralskikh gor|links=no}}), released by [[Sverdlovsk Film Studio]] in 1968, combined information about Bazhov's works with acted scenes from "The Mistress of the Copper Mountain", "The Stone Flower", "The Master Craftsman", "The Fire-Fairy", "The Twisted Roll", "That Spark of Life".{{cite AV media | people = [[Olgerd Vorontsov|Vorontsov, Olgerd]] (director) | date = 1968 | title = Сказы уральских гор | trans-title = Tales of the Ural Mountains | medium = Motion picture| language = Russian | url = http://www.net-film.ru/en/film-55307/ | access-date =8 December 2015 | format =mp4 | publisher =Russian Archive of Documentary Films and Newsreels| location =[[Sverdlovsk Film Studio]] }}{{cite web|url=http://www.kino-teatr.ru/doc/movie/sov/6474/annot|title=Сказы уральских гор |trans-title=Tales of the Ural Mountains|publisher=Kino-Teatr.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=8 December 2015}} ==== Animation ==== The animated film series based on the stories from ''The Malachite Box'' was made at Sverdlovsk Film Studio from the early 1970s to early 1980s, on time for the 100th anniversary since the birth of Pavel Bazhov. The series included the following films: ''Sinyushka's Well'' (1973), ''[[The Mistress of the Copper Mountain (film)|The Mistress of the Copper Mountain]]'' (1975), ''[[The Malachite Casket (film)|The Malachite Casket]]'' (1976), ''[[The Stone Flower (1977 film)|The Stone Flower]]'' (1977),{{cite web|url=http://www.animator.ru/db/?ver=eng&p=show_film&fid=5421 |title=A Stone Flower|publisher=Animator.ru|accessdate=22 November 2015}} ''Podaryonka'' (based on "Silver Hoof", 1978{{cite web|url=http://www.animator.ru/db/?ver=eng&p=show_film&fid=5442|title=A Little Present|publisher=Animator.ru|accessdate=1 December 2015}}), ''Golden Hair'' (1979), and ''The Grass Hideaway'' (1982).{{cite web|url=http://www.animator.ru/db/?ver=eng&p=show_film&fid=5432 |title=A Malachite Casket|publisher=Animator.ru|accessdate=22 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animator.ru/db/?ver=eng&p=show_film&fid=5430 |title=The Mistress of the Coppery Mountain|publisher=Animator.ru|accessdate=22 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.animator.ru/db/?ver=eng&p=show_film&fid=5420 |title=The Golden Hair|publisher=Animator.ru|accessdate=22 November 2015}} Three [[Traditional animation|hand-drawn]] animated films were released by [[Soyuzmultfilm]] in the 1970s: ''Silver Hoof'' in 1977 directed by [[Gennady Sokolsky]] and written by [[Genrikh Sapgir]],{{cite web|url=http://www.animator.ru/db/?ver=eng&p=show_film&fid=2769|title=A Little Silver Hoof|publisher=Animator.ru|accessdate=9 December 2015}} ''[[The Master Craftsman (film)|The Master Craftsman]]'' in 1978 directed by Inessa Kovalevskaya,{{cite web|url=http://www.animator.ru/db/?ver=eng&p=show_film&fid=2781 |title=Mining Master|publisher=Animator.ru|accessdate=22 November 2015}} was based on "The Stone Flower" and "The Master Craftsman"; ''[[The Fire-Fairy#The 1979 film|The Fire-Fairy]]'' in 1979 directed by Natalia Golovanova.{{cite web|url=http://www.animator.ru/db/?ver=eng&p=show_film&fid=2829 |title=Fire-Jumping|publisher=Animator.ru|accessdate=22 November 2015}} == Notes == {{Reflist|30em}} == References == {{commons category|Books by Pavel Bazhov}} * {{cite book|last=Bazhov|first=Pavel|authorlink=Pavel Bazhov|editor=Valentina Bazhova |editor2=[[Alexey Surkov]] |editor3=Yevgeny Permyak|title= Sobranie sochinenij v trekh tomakh|trans-title= Works.
